Answer:
Hi, my name is Hillary Tobias, and this is my video for the Session 9 Assignment. I'll start with the Define and Discover stage of the DRIVER framework. My objective for this assignment is to calculate the weighted average cost of capital for Netflix in connection with a hypothetical $5 billion investment decision. And finding this weighted average cost of capital will help decide if Netflix should take on this investment or not. The scope and horizon for this assignment will be using hypothetical Netflix data for this point in time to help make future decisions about the investment. The constraints for the assignment are that I am limited to the numbers that were provided, so I may need to make some assumptions. My success metric for this assignment will be correctly calculating the weighted average cost of capital for Netflix. And my benchmark for this assignment will be comparing Netflix to its industry peers, Disney and Amazon Prime Video. Continuing with the Define and Discover stage, I'll now discuss the data inventory that was provided for this assignment. I was given several hypothetical financial parameters for Netflix. First, I was given that their market capitalization is $200 billion. The book value of their debt is $14 billion. The current market value of their debt is $13 billion. Their current equity beta is 1.3. Their bond rating is BBB+ and the yield on those bonds is 5.8%. Their corporate tax rate is 21% and their current stock price is $450 per share. I was also given some market conditions for this assignment. The risk-free rate on a 10-year Treasury bill is $4.5%. The market risk premium is 5.5%. And the range for a typical weighted average cost of capital in the media industry is between 8 to 10%. I was also given some strategic context for this assignment. I was told that Disney's capital structure is 70% equity and 30% debt and its weighted average cost of capital is 8.2%. And I was told that Amazon Prime Video uses the Amazon corporate weighted average cost of capital, which is 9.5%. Lastly, I was given that Netflix is considering a $3 billion additional debt issuance for this content investment.

Now, I'll move on to the Represent stage of the DRIVER framework. I came up with five steps to help me complete this analysis for this assignment. My first step is to calculate the current weighted average cost of capital for Netflix. And in this step, I will find the current cost of equity using the CAPM formula, I will find the after-tax cost of debt, and then I will interpret the weighted average cost of capital. Step two will be to consider the $3 billion of additional debt financing. And in this step, I will find the new equity beta, the new cost of equity using CAPM, the new after-tax cost of debt, and the new weighted average cost of capital as a result of this additional debt financing. And then I will evaluate and explain how a change in capital structure affects company risk and cost of capital.

My third step will be to perform sensitivity analysis on key inputs such as beta and the market risk premium. And in this step, I'll also visualize how the weighted average cost of capital changes with debt levels. And then I will provide an analysis for optimal capital structure and financing strategy. In step four, I will consider project specific discount rates. I will use the divisional cost of capital concept to assess project-specific versus firm-wide discount rates. I will also assess risks related to the new project and I will provide a recommendation of the discount rate to use for this new project.

Lastly, in step five, I will do some competition and industry analysis. I will compare Netflix's cost of capital to its industry peers, and I will analyze Netflix's positioning in the industry and understand the competitive implications due to different costs of capital.

Now, I'll move on to the Implement stage of the DRIVER framework. In this stage, I provided Google Gemini with the facts of the case study, which were from the Define and Discover stage. And then I asked Google Gemini to write simple Python code to perform the steps from my Represent stage. And this code results in a full report-style output that provides a complete analysis of this hypothetical case study. Now I will switch over to Google Colab to show you my code. The code starts by defining some helper functions that will help format the output and make it look like a structured report. So, it prints headers and subheaders and various calculations and text. And then the code defines a function called "Run Netflix WACC Analysis," and this is the main function that will complete the analysis for Netflix.

It starts with part one which is where it does the baseline WACC calculation. So it starts by setting up the current financial parameters for Netflix. Its market capitalization was $200 billion, which is the value of the equity, and then it will use the market value of the debt for the total value of debt. And the reason we need to use the market value weights to calculate WACC is because they represent current investor expectations, whereas book values represent historical data that may not reflect true economic value. So, we use the market value of debt and then whenever we combine that value with the equity market capitalization, we can find the total market value of the firm. The current equity beta of Netflix was 1.3, and its pre-tax cost of debt was 5.8%. And its corporate tax rate was 21%. And then in the next section, it sets up the market conditions which are that the risk-free rate is 4.5%. And the market risk premium is 5.5%. The next section of code is where it prints all of these parameters so you know what numbers you're working with.

And then in step two, it calculates different component costs, and it starts with the CAPM formula to calculate the cost of equity. So, in this equation, it uses the risk-free rate, the current beta and the market risk premium to calculate the cost of equity, and then it will use that cost of equity in the calculation of weighted average cost of capital. And then it finds the after-tax cost of debt. And the reason we need to find the after-tax cost of debt is because businesses are able to deduct interest expenses from their taxes. And because of this, the net cost of a company's debt is the amount of interest it's paying minus the amount of interest it can deduct from its taxes. And this benefit is called the tax shield of debt. So, to find this we will take the cost of the debt before tax and multiply it by one minus the corporate tax rate and then the code displays its calculation for the after-tax cost of debt and then it moves on to calculating the weighted average cost of capital. In order to calculate that, the first thing it does is find the weights of equity and debt. So, it takes the value of the equity and divides that by the total firm value to find the weight of equity. And then it takes the market value of debt, divide that by the total firm value to find the weight of the debt. And so once it has all of these numbers calculated, to find weighted average cost of capital, it multiplies the weight of equity by the cost of equity and then adds the weight of debt multiplied by the cost of debt after tax. Next, the code prints the weighted average cost of capital formula and its calculation of that, and then its calculation of Netflix's current weighted average cost of capital, and then it also provides an interpretation of that number. 

Next, the code moves on to the scenario of the $3 billion of additional debt financing. So, it sets up the new parameters with the new debt issuance and calculating the new market value of the debt. It assumes that the equity value does not change, and then it calculates the total value of the firm and then it prints those parameters to show what numbers it is working with. And so, whenever a new company takes on additional debt, its beta will increase. And this is because the debt interest payments will have to be paid before any earnings are available to shareholders. And so shareholder returns become more volatile, so their systematic risk increases and beta goes up. So equity beta is currently levered. So the Hamada equation is used to find the unlevered beta, and then that same equation can be used to find the relevered beta with the new debt to equity ratio. So that is what the code does next. It first unlevers the current beta to find the asset beta, which is also known as the unlevered beta. And then it uses the new debt to equity ratio to find the new relevered beta. And then the code uses the new relevered beta in the CAPM formula to find the new cost of equity. And then once it finds the new cost of equity, it moves on to finding the new after-tax cost of debt. And so, we will make another assumption here because when a firm takes on more debt, it has a higher debt to equity ratio. And generally when a firm has a higher debt to equity ratio, it is seen as being a riskier company. So since the company will have higher risk, it will probably have to pay a higher interest rate on its debt. So the code is going to assume that the cost of debt will increase by 0.3%, so we use that to find the new cost of debt after tax. So then once it has all of these new numbers calculated, it will use the new weights of equity and debt and the new cost of equity and debt to find the new weighted average cost of capital, and then it will print those results and provide an analysis of how capital structure affects the risk and the cost of capital for Netflix. 

Next, the code moves on to the sensitivity and visualization, which was step three of my plan. It starts by doing some sensitivity analysis to market risk premium and beta. So, the market risk premium is currently 5.5%. So, it will analyze what would happen if the market risk premium was a little bit lower at 4.5% or a little bit higher at 6.5%. And then the equity beta is currently 1.3. So it will analyze what would happen if the beta was a little bit lower at 1.15, or if it was a little bit higher at 1.45. So, using these different assumptions, it will calculate the new weighted average cost of capital and then display those results and draw a conclusion. And then next it will move on to a visualization of how weighted average cost of capital changes as debt level changes. And so different amounts of debt will result in different debt to equity ratios. And so then the different debt to equity ratios result in different equity betas which changes the cost of equity. And so the code will need to use new weights for debt and equity and new cost of debt and equity to calculate a different weighted average cost of capital for each scenario it goes to. So first it sets up different assumptions for amounts of debt and interest rates on those debt amounts and then it recalculates the cost of equity and the weighted average cost of capital for all of those different debt levels. And then it will display all of those different levels in a chart so that we can compare them. And then it is also going to plot those different amounts of debt and weighted average cost of capital on a scatter plot. and so you can see how the weighted average cost of capital changes as the debt level changes. And then finally in this section, the code will provide a recommendation about whether Netflix should take on the $3 billion of additional debt or not. 

Next, the code moves on to step four of my plan, which was to consider project-specific discount rates. And so first it will discuss the use of a firm-wide weighted average cost of capital or one that is specific to a certain division or project. And then it will assess some different risks related to new projects and recommend a discount rate to use for this new project.

Then next the code defines a new function called "Run Competitive Analysis," and this will be used to compare Netflix to its peers, Disney and Amazon Prime. So it shows all of the different weighted average cost of capital for these different companies and then does a comparison of Netflix to Disney, a comparison of Netflix to Amazon, and finally ends with a conclusion about these comparisons and discusses some of the implications of the different weighted average cost of capital for each firm. Then lastly, the code calls the two main functions that it described to run the "Netflix Weighted Average Cost of Capital Analysis" and then the "Competitive Analysis." So I'll run this code so then you can see the output.

As you can see, it gave us this full report style output. Part one was the baseline weighted average cost of capital calculation. So, it displays all of the current financial parameters and market conditions, including the market cap of equity, the market value of debt, total firm value, equity beta, pre-tax cost of debt, corporate tax rate, risk-free rate, and market risk premium. And then the first calculation it performed was to find the cost of equity using the CAPM formula. So it took the risk-free rate and added the beta times the market risk premium and it found the cost of equity to be 11.65%.

And then it calculated the after-tax cost of debt, and that was found by taking the pre-tax cost of debt, which is 5.8%, and multiplying that by 1 minus the tax rate, which was 21%. And that resulted in an after-tax cost of debt of 4.58%.

Next it found the market value weights of equity and debt, and the weight of equity was 93.9% and the weight of debt was 6.1%. And those would have been found by taking, for example, the weight of equity was 200 billion and the total firm value was 213 billion. So 200 / 213 would result in the 93.9%. And then for the debt, 13 / 213 would result in 6.1%.

And so then it uses the weighted average cost of capital formula to find that number. And so it uses the weight of equity, which was 93.9%, multiplies that by the cost of equity which was, 11.65%, and then adds the weight of debt, which was 6.1%, multiplied by the after-tax cost of debt, which was 4.58%. And this resulted in a current weighted average cost of capital of 11.22% for Netflix. And then it provides an interpretation stating that this figure represents the blended after-tax cost of all of its capital including both equity and debt. And so, at a minimum, a typical project for Netflix must generate a return greater than this 11.22% hurdle rate to create value for its shareholders, and this is the baseline discount rate for new average risk investments.

Part two of the output was the scenario of taking on $3 billion of additional debt financing. And so here it will analyze the impact of this new debt to help finance the new investment. And this new debt would change the capital structure of the firm, which would in turn affect the cost of equity and potentially the cost of debt. First, it sets up the parameters for the new capital structure. The new market value of debt would be $16 billion, and the new total firm value would be $216 billion. So, using those new values, it found the new weight of equity to be 92.59% and the new weight of debt to be 7.41%.

As I discussed earlier when going through the code, this different capital structure would affect the beta. So then to find the new equity beta, it unlevered the current beta to find the firm's asset beta, and then it relevers beta using the new, higher debt capital structure. So, the current debt to equity ratio was 0.065. And so then it found the unlevered asset beta to be 1.237. And with the additional debt, the new debt to equity ratio is 0.08, and the new equity beta is 1.315, which was a slight increase from 1.3 previously. And so then it used that new equity beta to find the new cost of equity using the CAPM formula. And it found the cost of equity to be 11.73%, which was also a slight increase from 11.65% previously. And so, then it displays that slight change in cost of equity. And next it moves on to calculating the new after-tax cost of debt. And it states that it is assuming that taking on this additional debt will increase the firm's default risk. And it is going to assume that this will raise the pre-tax cost of debt by 30 basis points, or 0.3%, from 5.8% to 6.1%. So, the new pre-tax cost of debt is 6.1%, and that results in a new after-tax cost of debt of 4.82%. So, using all these new numbers, it calculates the new weighted average cost of capital. And so, the new weighted average cost of capital is pretty similar to the original. They both round to about 11.22%. As you can see, there's not a difference until about the seventh decimal place, so this was a slight decrease in the weighted average cost of capital.

And so then the code provides a quick analysis here of how capital structure affects risk and cost of capital. And so, the analysis shows that adding $3 billion in debt increased the debt-to-equity ratio from 0.065 to 0.08, and this had two main effects. The first effect was a higher risk, and since financial risk increased, the equity beta increased from 1.3 to 1.315, and the cost of debt increased from 5.8% to 6.1%. And these increases would increase the weighted average cost of capital. And then the second effect was that more debt means there is more tax-deductible financing, which also tends to be cheaper than equity financing. So, the after-tax cost of this new debt was 4.82%, and that is much lower than the cost of equity, which was 11.73%. And so, this would decrease the weighted average cost of capital. So, the first effect would have increased the weighted average cost of capital; the second effect decreased it. So, the net effect was that the weighted average cost of capital just changed slightly, it decreased slightly. And so that means that the benefit of the cheaper tax shield slightly outweighed the cost of the increased financial risk, resulting in the minor change to the overall weighted average cost of capital.

Next is part three of my plan which was the sensitivity visualization and analysis of capital structure. It starts with the sensitivity analysis of some key inputs, such as the market risk premium and beta. So, whenever the market risk premium decreased to 4.5%, the weighted average cost of capital decreased to 10%. And if the market risk premium was higher at 6.5%, the weighted average cost of capital was also higher at 12.44%. And if the beta would have been lower at 1.15, the weighted average cost of capital would have been lower at 10.44%. And if the beta would have been higher at 1.45, the weighted average cost of capital also would have been higher at 11.99%. So, from this analysis, we can see that the weighted average cost of capital is highly sensitive to both the market risk premium and the firm's equity beta because these directly and significantly drive the cost of equity, which in this case is a significant part of Netflix's capital structure at $200 billion.

The next part of code is the visualization and scenario modeling of how weighted average cost of capital changes with changes in debt levels. So to find the optimal capital structure, we need to model how the cost of capital will change as debt increases. So, as debt rises the cost of debt and the cost of equity both rise due to risk. And so, the optimal point will be where the weighted average cost of capital is minimized.

So what the code does here is assume those different debt levels and find the new value of the debt out of the total firm value. And then it calculates the new pre-tax cost of debt based on the level of debt, and then finds the new cost of equity, and then uses all of these new numbers to find the weighted average cost of capital. So, it starts with a debt level of zero for the baseline. And so, this would be a fully equity financed firm, and so in that case, it's weighted average cost of capital would be the same as its cost of equity. And for this scenario it calculated that to be 11.3%. And then you can see as the level of debt increases, the pre-tax cost of debt also increases because risk increases, and the cost of equity increases as risk increases, but the tax shield benefit that is provided by the debt actually decreases the weighted average cost of capital to begin with. So at $13 billion of debt, we saw that the weighted average cost of capital would be 11.22%. And then we also analyzed the additional $3 billion of debt financing and found a similar weighted average cost of capital at 11.22%, but as we saw earlier, that is actually slightly lower than the $13 billion debt level. And then you can see after that, as the debt level continues to increase up to say $25 billion, $35 billion and $45 billion, the weighted average cost of capital starts increasing again. And this is because too much debt results in higher default risk of the firm, and that begins to outweigh the tax shield benefit of the debt. And this graph created by the code helps to see this. So the blue dots are these various debt levels. And then the vertical axis shows the weighted average cost of capital. And then all of these dots are connected by this U-shaped gray line. And so this shows that initially as the debt level increases, the weighted average cost of capital will decrease because of that tax shield benefit. But then as debt continues to increase, the weighted average cost of capital will begin to increase again. And so this red line shows Netflix's current debt level of $13 billion. And the green line shows the new debt level with $3 billion of additional debt financing. And based on this you can see that the weighted average cost of capital appears to be minimized at the debt level around $13 to $16 billion. And so, the recommendation is that this $3 billion debt issuance seems to be a good move because it takes advantage of the tax shield without significantly increasing risk and results in a lower weighted average cost of capital, which is the goal.

Next, the code moves on to part four of my plan, which was assessing project-specific discount rates. And so, the code says that the firm-wide weighted average cost of capital of 11.22% represents the average risk of all Netflix operations. And so, using this as a hurdle rate is only appropriate for projects that have the exact same risk profile as the company average. And an example of this would be another safe US-based content renewal. But for this $5 billion content investment decision that we're analyzing, it would probably not be appropriate to use the company-wide weighted average cost of capital because the investment's risk will probably differ from the company average, and the divisional cost of capital concept states that we should use different discount rates for different business units or different projects such as US versus international projects. So, then the code discusses several risk components of the new investment that need to be considered. The first risk is if it is for US or international content because those will have different risks involved with them. Risks related to US content are primarily market and competitive risks that are well understood, such as major and well-funded US-based competitors like Disney Plus, Max and Amazon Prime. The US economy, currency, and political system are considered to be stable and predictable, so those don't really create risks surrounding US content. However, international content has all of these same risks as US content plus some additional ones, such as currency, political and market acceptance risks. Currency risk is a major factor in this. Netflix earns revenue in the local currency of whatever country the content is in, but it will report its earnings in US dollars. So, if the US dollar gets stronger, foreign revenues translate into fewer dollars, which will hurt Netflix's financial performance. And then another risk is political risk, which is a concern because governments in other countries might impose new rules like content censorship or impose new taxes on streaming services, and so that could also hurt Netflix. And then market acceptance is also a risk because a concept for a show might not translate well across cultures. So, because of these additional risks, the weighted average cost of capital for an international project should be higher than it is for a US project. Another risk to be considered is if the project is for new intellectual property or for an established franchise. A new experimental project is a lot riskier than something that is already well-established, so the new intellectual property would require a higher discount rate. And then a third risk to consider is the business model for the new project. If it is content for the core subscription business of Netflix, then that is not very risky because it's consistent with its main business operations. But if the project is something such as a new, untested, advertising-supported tier of subscription, then that would include more risk and require a higher cost of capital rate assumption.

So whenever it comes to selecting a discount rate for this project, it recommends probably not using the firmwide discount rate of 11.22%. The rate would need to be adjusted for the specific risk of the investment. So, you would start with the baseline for the rate using the 11.22% firm-wide and then adjust from there. So, if the project is a safe, US franchise content, then you could just use the baseline weighted average cost of capital. But then if this is kind of an average mix of content that's not too risky, just add about one to two percent. But if this is something that is very new and it is international content, then you would add probably 3 to 5% to the discount rate. And specifically, if the project is for an international content production, a country risk premium would need to be added to the calculation of CAPM, which would increase the weighted average cost of capital. And different countries will add different levels of risk to a project based on that specific country's economic and political position. So the $5 billion investment's cash flow should be discounted using a rate that reflects its specific risk profile, which will probably be in the 12 to 16% range.

Now the output shows the last part of my plan, which was the competitive and industry analysis. It starts by showing the weighted average cost of capital for Netflix, which was 11.22%, the weighted average cost of capital for Disney, which is 8.2%, and Amazon's corporate weighted average cost of capital, which was 9.5%. Then it also tells that the average industry range in the media industry for weighted average cost of capital is about 8 to 10%. And so, it analyzes that Netflix's weighted average cost of capital is the highest of the group and it is also above the industry average. And this high cost of capital is a competitive disadvantage for Netflix. And these differences are driven by two main factors - the business model and the capital structure of Netflix.

It starts by comparing Netflix to Disney. So it states that Disney is a diversified conglomerate and any weaknesses from its streaming service can be offset by its massive, stable cash flows from its parks and resorts and merchandise, and this lowers Disney's overall systematic risk, and therefore its cost of equity, and therefore its weighted average cost of capital. And then on the other hand, Netflix is entirely based on its subscriber growth and content hits. So, it is a much riskier, more volatile investment, which demands a higher cost of equity and therefore a higher weighted average cost of capital. And then also analyzing capital structure, Disney uses a significant amount of debt financing, which tends to be cheaper than equity financing. Disney has about 30% debt, and this provides that tax shield benefit and pulls its blended weighted average cost of capital down. And then on the other hand, we saw that Netflix uses only about 6% debt and is almost entirely equity financed, so it doesn't get as much benefit from that tax shield benefit and has a higher weighted average cost of capital.

And then when comparing Netflix to Amazon, this is Amazon's corporate weighted average cost of capital because Amazon Prime Video is not a standalone business. So Amazon's corporate weighted average cost of capital is more heavily influenced and lowered by its high profit and stable Amazon Web Services cloud division and its e-commerce services. So those services kind of subsidize its video business. And so this means that Amazon's hurdle rate for content is different, and its goal isn't necessarily to profit from the video, but to retain its high-spending Prime members. And so this allows Amazon to overpay for content, whereas Netflix cannot do that. Netflix has to earn a return greater than 11.22% on the content itself.

So since weighted average cost of capital is the hurdle rate for new investments, Netflix's high 11.22% hurdle rate is a significant competitive disadvantage for it. A way to illustrate this is that if there was a project with a 10% expected return, it would be rejected by Netflix because it is lower than its weighted average cost of capital at 11.22%. But Disney could accept this project because 10% is greater than its weighted average cost of capital of 8.2%. And so Amazon would be in a similar boat there. And this gives Disney and Amazon more flexibility to bid on content, invest in new markets, and be more patient with financial returns. And Netflix is more positioned as the high-risk, high growth, 'pure play' leader, and it cannot win a cheap capital war. Instead, it has to be a superior capital allocator and chase high return homerun content to justify its high cost of capital and satisfy investors. So basically, since Disney and Amazon are more diversified, their weighted average cost of capital is lower and any losses from their streaming services can be offset by profits from the other goods and services they provide. But Netflix has to make money from its streaming services because that is pretty much its only line of business. 

Now I'll switch back to my slides and continue with the Validation stage of the DRIVER framework. So in order to validate my analysis, I first checked Netflix's weighted average cost of capital to see if it was comparable to its industry peers, and it was slightly higher, but it was still pretty close, so I felt good about that. I also checked the formulas that the code used, and I manually calculated the relevered beta, the CAPM calculations, and the weighted average cost of capital calculations, and those all resulted in the same thing as the code, so that was good. And then just as an additional double check, I verified with online calculators, and all of my results were still good, and the code ran smoothly. 

Now I'll move on to the Evolve stage of the DRIVER framework. So from this assignment we saw that Netflix will use its weighted average cost of capital to evaluate taking on this new $5 billion investment or not. So, generally, companies use their weighted average cost of capital as the benchmark for accepting or rejecting long-term investments. And projects that are expected to earn a return at least equal to a company's weighted average cost of capital are accepted because that means they will cover the cost of financing. But projects that have a return that fall below the company's weighted average cost of capital are rejected because they destroy firm value. So, in this case, Netflix will accept this project if it will earn a return of 11.22% or greater. And then this application can be extended to other companies in other industries to evaluate projects for those companies and determine if they should be accepted or rejected.

Finally, I'll move on to the Reflect stage of the DRIVER framework. So, one of the biggest takeaways from this assignment was how capital structure significantly impacts a company's weighted average cost of capital. I saw that when a company is fully equity financed, it does not receive any of the tax shield benefit from debt, and its weighted average cost of capital is the same as its cost of equity. But then as the company takes on debt, its weighted average cost of capital decreases because the tax shield benefit is greater than its risk of bankruptcy. But then as debt continues to increase, it does eventually become too high, and the risk of bankruptcy outweighs that tax shield benefit, and the weighted average cost of capital begins to increase again. So, what I can learn from this is that the weighted average cost of capital is a balancing act of finding an ideal capital structure. It requires companies to find the right mix of debt and equity financing that will minimize its weighted average cost of capital. Thanks!

Answer: Hi, my name is Andrea. In session nine, I'm working on one main question. What hurdle rate does a company need to earn so that both deb holders and shareholders are satisfied? To make it concrete, I imagine I'm the new CFO of Tech Forward, Inc. The CEO shows three projects, each needing $100 million. First one, Project Alpha, that's an AI research lab. Expected return is about 15%. Then project beta which is a manufacturing expansion and the expected return would be 12%. And third project gamma an international expansion with an expected return of 9%. We can only pick two out of the three options. So my first thought was I need to compare this returns to the company's cost of uh cost of capital. That cost of capital is the WACC the weighted average cost of capital. And in this session I will use driver to understand what WACC is, how to calculate it and how to use it as a hurdle rate for these projects. First in the driver method I will I will define and discover. I define the problem the the problem with two main sources of money. Sorry. Tech forward uses two main sources of money which are equity and debt. Equity is the money from shareholders and debt is the money from bonds and loans. Shareholders want a higher return because they take more risk and lenders want interest and want to be paid back on time. So the company's true cost of capital is not just the interest rate on debt or the return shareholders want. It's the average of both the weighted by how much of each we use that that average is the WACC. My goals in this session are first to understand what goes into WACC which are the cost of equity, the after tax cost of depth and the market value, weight of depth and equity. Then I want to see how WACC becomes a hurdle rate for projects like Alpha, Beta and Gamma. And I want to connect this to my Netflix assignment where I'll estimate ne Netflix's WACC and decide if a 5 billion content investment clears that hurdle. I also connect back to earlier sessions with the time value of money, bond pricing, CAPM, and the market efficiency. Now, the WACC puts all of that into one number the CFO can actually use. Then I'm going to represent my problem. I represent WACC in a way that's easy to remember. WACC is the average return the company must pay all investors based on how much equity and depth it uses. That's putting it in simple words. The steps there's five steps which are the first one is to find the market value of equity. Uh the formula is shares outstanding times stock price. Then to find the market value of debt and to do that we use the market value of bonds or loans not just the face value. Third to compute the weights. There's two formula for this two formulas for this. The equity weight formula which is equity value divided between equity plus depth and the depth weight formula which is depth value divided by equity plus depth. Fourth, I estimate the component costs. To do that, the cost of equity for from CAPM, we use this formula, which is risk-free rate plus beta times market risk premium. Then the cost of depth is the current yield on debt and the after tax cost of depth would be cost of depth times 1 minus the tax rate. The fifth step, the fifth step is to blend them where the where the formulas would be for WACC equity weight times cost of equity and depth weight times after tax cost of depth. This one number is the hurdle rate and the projects with a return above WACC create value while the projects with a return below WACC destroy value. Obviously, we want uh the project with a return above wacc. Then we implement um I'm going to implement with the code you can see in the screen. Um I'm going to show you how to implement with a very simple code. In this session here, I pretend Tech Forward is financed with 40% equity, 60% depth. Depth cost 6% before tax and tax and the tax rate is 25%. The cost of equity comes from VCAPM. So let's say risk-free rate is 4% uh market risk premium is 5% and beta is 1.2. I wrote a small Python example like this one. And this code takes simple inputs we talk about in class, calculates the cost of equity using CAPM, adjust the cost of depths for um taxes and blends them into WACC. If this prints a WACC around let's say 9% then that becomes the tech forwards hurdle rate and then I have to compare it. Here you can see obviously the here um I did it in Python instead of showing it in Google Gemini for this session and you can see what the co so we can see what the code returns um so I now have to compare it I compare project alpha which is 50% which is um larger than wcc meaning it creates value project beta is also larger than WACC meaning it also creates value but product gamma project gamma is 9% almost the same as WACCC which it's barely at the hurdle so based on WACC alpha and beta look much better than gamma if I have to choose two projects now I have to verify um my work in this verify stage I ask myself does my WACCC make a number makes sense. So I would check are my inputs reasonable? Is it risk-f free? Real risk-free rate realistic is a market risk premium in the range we use in class. Is a beta typical for a company like this? Are the weights based on market values, not book values? And is my WACCC in a reasonable range compared to similar companies? I can also change inputs a little to see how sensitive the WACC is. If interest rates rates rise, the cost of debt goes up then WACC rises too. The if the firm takes on more debt beta may rise, meaning the cost of equity goes up and tax rate changes also move the after tax cost of debt. This helps me see that the WACCC is an estimate I can move when the market changes because we have to be careful with not only the code but for it to be reasonable. Then I evolve in evolve I think about where WACC shows up beyond this simple tech forward example. Once I know how to calculate WACC I can use it as a discount range rate in NPV and capital budgeting. I can also use it in valuation where WACC discounts free cash flows. I can also use it as a performance benchmark comparing returns to WACC and I can also study how changing the mix of depth and equity changes WACC in capital structure problems. So now to reflect uh which is the last driver step to wrap it up. The main thing I learned in session 9 is that WACC is the bridge between investors and managers. Investors say given the risk, here's the return we need. WACC turns that into a clear rule for managers and we only accept projects that earn more than this rate for tech forward. That means using WACC to choose between alpha, beta, and gamma. So for me, WACC is no longer just a formula. It's the minimum return the company must earn to keep all of its capital providers satisfied and to make smart discipline investment decisions. Thank you. This is what I learned for session 9. Uh, putting it in a example.

So from the question I see that the market cap here is 200 billion. Market value of debt is 13 billion. Um the equity beta is 1.3. The risk-free rate is 4.5% and the corporate tax rate is 20%. Next, we want to show how to calculate the cost of equity which implicates the CAPM by taking the risk-free rate and adding the risk premium. So, it' be the 4.5%. plus the 1.3 times the 5.5% market risk premium. And then next here after that to calculate the cost of debt after tax, we would do one minus the tax rate. So it would be the debt yield times one minus the tax rate. So you can get these numbers here as well. Next, the two variables here of unlever data and rollover data uses an equation to accurately model how changing the capital structure impacts equity risk. So, we take, you know, D and E up here, plug it in, we find what needs to be done that we'll get into a little bit later.

So first we wanted to do the current WACC calculation. So the cost of um equity which is K is calculated here because you take the RF rate current and the MRP. So it' be 4.5% plus 1.3 * 5.5%. Which if we run the code gives you 11.65%. Next, for the after tax cost of debt, it would be 4.58%. As you can see here, because you would take the 5.8% times the 1 minus 0.21 from the numbers given within the problem and then waiting these cost yields a current whack of 11.23%. Which is our initial hurdle rate.

And then we also calculated the weight of debt here as you can see.

And then next for the whack after the $3 billion debt um issuance. Here's that one. So you just take the um asset beta which is 1.23. Oh, wait. Uh the the pure B business risk is 1.23 and then the within with the change in the beta, it changing to 1.35. And so this higher beta increases the new cost of equity to 11.91% as you can see in this code. But because of the benefit of a cheaper tax shielded debt, the new whack actually drops slightly to 11.19%.

And this confirms that the debt issuance is a financially sound decision as it lowers the firm's overall capital by 0.4%. You can see the change in whack here with the new rack and the change in whack, which is basically what I was touching earlier. Next, in terms of qualitative analysis, the output confirms a single rate is inadequate at 11.22%. For a course prospects like core US content, but for the international content, we could see that um it has a higher currency and political risk. So, we have to use an adjusted higher discount rate. So, for instance, adding a 2% risk premium or bring the hurdle rate to 13.23% for these high-risk markets.

Then next we can see here we compare the Netflix whack which is 11.23 to the Disney whack of 8.20 that was given. So because Disney's lower whack, we would say that it's due to lower business risks or diversified revenue and a more optimized capital structure, higher debt and maximizing tax shield, which is basically the reason why that is. And then finally um

from the output here, I made a chart for sensitivity analysis as a visualization. So first the optimal f financing strategy is that uh the $3 billion debt insurance has to be a case. So we take the difference in the scenario from above and just plug all these numbers in find the new beta K whack all those numbers and then we come here and as we uh move the whack down we could see that the debt to value ratio uh goes down as we go down. And so to just reflect on all that, we would say that the debt issuance lowered the whack, indicating Netflix is underleveraged. And then a recommendation would be to utilize strategic debt financing.

Hi, my name is Daniel Verachtert and this is my session nine Netflix whack assignment. Okay, so to start the CAPM the cost of equity for uh Netflix the expected return is 11.65%. Uh since the beta is 1.3 which is relatively high it means Netflix is 30% more volatile in the market. For this reason, investors require almost a 12% return to hold Netflix stock. Uh the cost of debt after tax that found to be 4.58%. Uh the Netflix bond carries a BBB plus credit rating with a yield of 5.8%. Once again, after taxes, this drops to 4.58%. Debt is much cheaper for Netflix than equity. So in their case, it's 4.6% versus 11.6%. Uh this creates an opportunity using reasonable amounts of debt lowers Netflix's overall whack. Current capital structure weight. Uh I found that the almost 94% of Netflix's financing comes from shareholders. Only 6% comes from debt. Because Netflix uses so little debt, its whack is dominated by high cost of equity. Uh so the current whack is 11.21%. This is uh this is a high cost of capital or that this is because of the high cost of capital. It's driven by heavy equity dependence and the minimum return Netflix must make to satisi satisfy shareholders and lenders is 11.21%.

uh the whack after the new $3 billion debt issuance would uh come out to be 11.13% which is just like looks minimal but has a substantial effect. Um add adding debt increases Netflix's debt weight from or increases Netflix's debt weight from 6% to 7.4% 4% instead is much cheaper than equity. Adding more of it pulls whack downwards. This shows that Netflix was under uh underlevered before. Um there's room to safely take on more debt to lower whack further. Uh the project specific whack. So uh as for the US content, I got that the US whack would be 10.2%. 2% uh US content should use a lower hurdle. This is due to the US having lower risk. Uh the reasons for this lower risk and lower back is because of strong brand presence in the US, predictable subscriber behavior, more reliable data models, and more stable cash flows. Um, as for international content, I found that the whack was 12.3%. Uh, international projects require higher hurdle rates. This is due to the international content having higher risk. Uh, reasons for this higher risk are political risk, currency volatility, local content, uncertainties, and different licensing and censorship rules. So now moving on to the Netflix versus Disney comparison. So Netflix their whack is 11.21 and Disney is 8.2. The main reason for Netflix is higher uh whack is they have lower risk and use more debt. Therefore they have cheaper capital. Uh if we take a look at this chart that's down here uh these are different factors. So leverage Netflix is very low while Disney is higher with 30% debt. Uh their business models are different. So it's like Netflix is a single line. It's just streaming whereas Disney is diversified. So it's park studios, ESPN. They have different fields. Uh the beta once again Netflix is at 1.3 which is relatively high and risky or not that risky but somewhat more than Disney which is at 1.1. Uh competitive mode the Netflix has a much narrower competitive mode while Disney has a stronger IP and legacy assets. And then the credit quality Netflix is a BBB plus while Disney is A minus uh range historically. So the optimal capital structure strategy would be gradually increase leverage to 15 to 20% debt which is now currently 6%. This would lower whack by 50 to 120 bps, still maintain investment grade rate while still maintaining the same investment grade rating. Uh then match funding types to project risk. So use lower whack for US content and use higher whack for international content. Uh three, use fixed rate debt to hedge interest rates during volatile markets. And then four, do not target Amazon level flexibility. Netflix lacks Amazon's diversified cash flows, but it should emulate Disney's balance financing. In conclusion, Netflix should use moderate leverage and apply project specific hurdle rates, reducing its overall cost of capital while maintaining financial flexibility.

Okay, so for this project we are looking at basically a decision that Netflix is making with a $5 billion content investment decision and we're seeing what kind of, if they should take on more debt or basically keep a heavy equity based company and we're going to do that. So, for Define and Discover, Netflix is evaluating a $5 billion content investment which they are considering financing through a $3 billion additional debt issuance. So for this, we're going to need to calculate Netflix's current WACC, recalculate WACC after a new $3 billion debt, determine project-specific WACC such as U.S. content and international content, compare this to Disney's 8.2% and Amazon's 9.5%. And then we're going to recommend optimal capital structure strategy. So we were using a Python program to calculate CAPM, cost of equity, after tax, cost of debt, current and post debt WAC, and WAC sensitivity versus leverage.

We have some provided financial inputs such as a $200 billion market cap, a $13 billion market value debt, a $3 billion proposed new debt, 1.3 equity beta, 4.5% risk-free rate, 5.5% market risk premium, a BBB plus bond rating, a 5.8% Netflix bond yield, a 21% corporate tax rate, 8-10% industry WAC, and then we have Disney with an 8.2% and Amazon with a 9.5%.

So for the represent stage, we're gonna basically we're gonna list some of the information we need And we're gonna need to use a variety of equations to find out the information that we'll be using to make our decision So for this will you using cost of equity which will estimate the return on equity investors require based on market risk We have the equation right here And then we'll do after tax cost of debt which calculates the effective cost of debt after getting the tax shield from the interest deductibility The equation is right below it right here Capital Structure Weights determines the percentage of financing that comes from equity versus debt, with the two equations below it. Weighted Average Cost of Capital, which is WAC, which combines equity and debt costs into blended required return for the firm, using this equation here. And then New Debt Amount for Post-Issuance, which basically just updates the firm's debt level after issuing new debt.

So for our implement, we're using a program in Colab to basically do all of this for us and then list all of the returns from the equations. So here is my script right here. Top part imports all the tools that we're going to need. We're going to move down and it's going to list default inputs for the problem that are provided from the Textbook, and then it's going to set up the user inputs. And then it's going to collect the user inputs. It has all the listed formulas right below that. And then it's going to calculate these formulas using the collected user inputs. And then it's going to plot the graphs, and then basically print the statement of all the results that we got throughout this. So if we run this right here, we are going to just use the default Use the default values that come from the problem, and then we're going to get this return right here so we have the Just simple calculations up here. We have a whack versus leverage table, and then we have a wax sensitivity graph and

So we're going to take these results. So it has a cost of equity of 11.5%. This means the expected return from Netflix equity investors reflects Netflix being slightly more volatile, which has a higher risk rate free because investors require more compensation for risk. We have an after tax cost of debt of 4.58%, which shows Netflix's cost of borrowing after accounting for a 21% tax shield. And then it shows that debt is cheaper than equity because interest is tax deductible. We have a current WAC of 11.21%, which is a hurdle rate for new Netflix investments, and then this means that projects must return more than 11.21% in order to be valid. We have a WAC after new debt of 11.13%, which is slightly lower than the previous WAC, which means that the capital structure becomes slightly more leveraged and shows that Netflix is very equity heavy. And then our WACC sensitivity table shows WACC decreases as debt ratio increases.

And this kind of illustrates the trade-off of theory, trade-off theory of capital structure. And then we have our plot right here with our current WACC far to the top left. And it shows that as WACC increases, our weighted average cost of capital, or as our, yeah, as our debt to capital ratio increases, our weight to cost of capital, weighted average cost of capital decreases. So that's the relationship it has. It's also shown within the table of the WACC versus leverage data. So then moving on to the validate, we have the, we're going to calculate the cost of equity and final cost of equity to kind of, or cost of equity and current WACC to kind of validate and make sure that the program is working correctly. So here we have the equation 1.3 times 0.055 which equals 0.0715 and then we're going to add 0.045 to that and get the 11.65% which matches up with And then for the WAC we are going to do .058 times 1 minus .21 and then which will equal .058 times .79 which gives us a 4.

58% which also lines up with the program. So, to evolve this, moving on to the evolve stage, we're going to just do some analysis on this. Based on the current WAC, any project that will return more than 11.21% should be pursued. This decreases to 11.13% after the new debt, which shows that debt will slightly reduce WAC, which indicates debt is cheaper than the current equity that they have. Moderate additional debt is beneficial for financing content investment. Cost of equity versus after-tax cost of debt shows that equity is more expensive than debt, confirming the strategic use of debt can lower the cost of capital. Netflix's whack is higher than both Disney and Amazon, which they could reduce this by further increasing debt but still maintain flexibility with equity compared to Disney and Amazon. They're basically just a lot higher because they hold a lot more equity compared to those two companies.

I think that Netflix should maintain moderate leverage to lower WAC while keeping flexibility. They can use debt to partially fund content investment and avoid over-reliance on equity. So moving on to Reflect, there's some things that I noticed about this and then we can move on with this. The debt issuance had a pretty small impact on WACC, which I think is surprising. This overall shows how equity-heavy Netflix as a company is. And then even with cheaper debt, Netflix's overall WACC remains high due to a large equity portion. So this overall process that we just did can be applied to any new investment or expansion project. by adjusting the data needed. Some restrictions is this model assumes a constant beta which is not the reality. The reality would lead to a slightly increased equity cost. I also think it's surprising that using SumDep can actually lower WACC even for a huge equity company such as Netflix.

So overall we can just kind of allow our findings show that the effects that these have that the debt has on Netflix is kind of restricted by its heavy equity and then it's high whack and things like that are due to its high equity. So that's the basics of this analysis.

Answer:
Hello, this is my session 9 assignment for Management 310. So to go ahead and start, we start with the Define and Discover. And essentially, the stage focuses on clearly understanding the investment decision, validating all of the financial parameters, and also defining the strategic scope of the capital structure. So just to give a quick overview of the actual problem that we're looking to solve today. Okay, so Netflix is evaluating a hypothetical $5 billion content investment and considering funding a $3 billion of this through new debt. It assesses the viability of this investment and the efficiency of the funding strategy. So we must determine the company's weighted average cost of capital, the WACC. The analysis must determine if the returns justify the cost capital and how increasing leverage impacts shareholder value compared to peers like Disney.

So our goal for this problem is to produce a rigorous quantitative calculation of Netflix's current pro-forma WACC providing a strategic recommendation on capital structure optimization based on the tradeoff between tax yields and financial distress costs. So, and a very important first step is the fact verification. So, a common analytical error is using the book value of debt instead of the market value when calculating WACC. We must explicitly verify and utilize the market value of debt, which is $13 billion, provided in hypothetical parameters, rather than the book value, which is $14 billion, to reflect the true opportunity for cost of capital.

Our hypothesis is given a high equity beta 1.3, Netflix costs of equity will likely be high, driving the WACC upward. However, the addition of $3 billion in debt is a relatively low cost at 5.8%, compared to the overall WACC due to the tax yield effect, provided the added risk does not spike the beta or credit spread significantly. So the action we'll take is to confirm the risk-free rate, which is a 4.5%, and the market risk premium, which is 5.5%, align with the provided market context to ensure that the CAPM calculation is inherently, is internally consistent.

Our communication plan is if the calculated weighted average cost of capital differs significantly from the media industry range, which is 8 to 10 percent, the variance must be explained by analyzing specific risk factors, like the beta 1.3, rather than assuming calculation error. And then some of the key questions that we're going to answer throughout the problem: what is Netflix's current cost of equity using the CAPM inputs? How does the inclusion of the tax yield 21% rate impact the cost of debt? How does the issuance of $3 billion in new debt lower the weighted average cost of capital enough to create a shareholder value or does it introduce excessive financial risk? Why does Netflix's WACC differ from Disney's and Amazon's? And is this difference justified by their business models? And lastly, should the $5 billion investment be evaluated against the firm-wide WACC or just a project-specific discount rate? For example, international versus domestic content.

Now going on to the representation, which is the plan. So this stage essentially outlines the analytical and technical steps required to calculate the WACC components and evaluate the strategic implementations of the new debt issuance. So some of our core formulas and methodology is as follows. The analysis will be centered around the weighted average cost of capital, the WACC, formula to determine the hurdle rate, supported by the CAPM, the Capital Asset Pricing Model, for the equity component. So first we can see the cost of equity equals the risk-free rate plus the equity beta times the market risk premium. The after-tax cost of debt equals the pre-tax yield times one minus the tax rate, and then our weighted average cost of capital is calculated with E defined as the market value of equity, D defined as market value of debt, V is the total market value, the cost of debt is COD, and then T is our corporate tax rate.

Now moving on to the analytical process. The process will be conducted in a sequential and calculated manner. Our step one, the component calculation and weighting is a critical gate. Cost of equity using the provided parameters 4.5% plus 1.3 times the 5.5. To calculate our after cost of debt and determine current capital structure weights using market capitalization to $200 billion and the market value of debt to $13 billion. And just as a quick note, as we mentioned before, we're not using the book value of $14 billion. Our second step is the baseline weighted average cost of capital, the WACC determination. So compute the firm-wide weighted average cost of capital and then compare this result against the industry range 8 to 10 percent to validate if Netflix is trading at a premium or discount to peers.

Our third step is a sensitivity analysis, which is the $3 billion issuance. Adjust the total debt to reflect the new $3 billion issuance, so it's $13 billion plus the $3 billion, which is the new $16 billion. And then recalculate the weights based on the new capital structure. Calculate the new weighted average cost of capital, assuming that the cost of debt and beta remain constant for the marginal issuance. And then our analysis for this is to quantify the basis point reduction in the weighted average cost of capital resulting from the additional tax shield.

Our fourth step is a comparative analysis between Netflix and Disney. We're going to compare the calculated Netflix weighted average cost of capital against Disney's 8.2%. We're going to deconstruct the difference by asking these questions. Is it driven by capital structure where Disney is 30% debt versus Netflix has lower leverage, or business risk, Disney's diversified revenue streams versus Netflix's pure play streaming model? Our fifth step is a project-specific risk assessment. So evaluate if the $5 billion content investment matches the firm's average risk profile. Differentiate between the domestic content, likely lower risk, potentially below the WACC, versus the international content, a higher risk due to currency/regulatory issues potentially requiring a premium above the WACC. Our sixth step is the strategic recommendation for the synthesized problems to recommend whether Netflix should proceed with a debt issuance and address the optimal capital structure, such as adding the more debt, that move Netflix closer to an optimal point, lowering the cost of capital, or push it forward to financial distress.

Some of the technical requirements for our problem here is we're going to be using tools like Excel or Financial Calculator for the WACC, and then our deliverables are a calculation table showing inputs with pre-tax/after-tax costs, weights, and the final WACC for both current and pro forma scenarios. Our next step is the execution. The most crucial step in Proof is to execute step one to perform the CAPM calculation to lock in the cost of equity as it's the largest driver of WACC for tech/media company with Netflix valuation.

Our third section here is the implementation, which is the analysis and the code. So our goal is to execute the WACC calculation for the current state in the pro forma debt issuance scenario and determine the appropriate hurdle rates for the investment decision. Our action is to create an integrated Python model that we utilize to compute the component cost, which is the cost of equity and cost of debt, capital structure weights, and the final WACC. So we went on ahead and asked Gemini the first three parts of our driver method and asked it to create code for us here using a python model so I went ahead and I exported it into CoLab, which we can see here. We have part one of it, which is defining our inputs. So here are different variables. We have the company data for Netflix, we have the market data, and we also have competitor data. So we have Disney's and Amazon's. Part two, we calculate the cost of equity and debt. So here we have the equations that we're using, and also the cost of debt, so the equations that we're using as well.

Part three is to calculate the current WACC, so just some more equations, the total firm value to calculate the weight, to form the cost of equity here, the cost of debt here, and part four our scenario so it's additional debt issuance so a new debt amount. Generally I also utilize the KISS principle—keep it stupid simple—for simplistic model. Part five our project specific analysis and then finally part six our comparison and recommendation as well so it compares Netflix with Disney and Amazon and then also provides some recommendations with an analysis for why. So then when we went ahead and ran this we were able to receive this result our starting analysis for Netflix just some more definitions our current scenario and project specific and then our analysis.


Netflix cost of capital is higher than Disney's and the reasoning for that is that Disney has a 30 percent debt while Netflix only has 6.1 percent debt. Since debt which is approximately 4.6 is cheaper than equity which is 11.6. Disney's higher leverage lowers their WACC. So the recommendation is to proceed with the $3 billion debt issuance and it lowers the WACC slightly because the debt is cheaper than equity. Our second recommendation is to use a project-specific WACC for the $5 billion dollar investment. If the content is for stable markets in the U.S., use 11.2%. If exploring new volatile markets, then we would use a higher rate.

So now going back to our implementation, we have a quick financial analysis of the calculations as well. So first is component costs. Analysis first established the cost of equity and debt. So here we have the cost of equity and the cost of debt. So our interpretation of these after being calculated is that the significant spread between the cost of equity and the cost of debt indicates a strong potential for lowering the overall cost of capital by increasing the proportion of cheaper debt. Here we see the cost of equity is about 11.6% and the cost of debt is 4.6%. Our current WACC calculation using the cost of the market value of equity which is the 200 billion and the market value of debt which is the 13 billion. So you see here So our equities, $200 billion, our weight is 93.9%, our cost is 11.65%, and our contribution is 10.94%. For debt, it's the same thing with $13 billion in our amount, our weight is 6.1%, our cost is 4.58%, and our contribution is 0.28%. And then at the bottom here, we just totaled all of these up, and for cost, it's our WACC, and we can see our weight equals 100 as well.

A third is the scenario analysis, $3 billion debt issuance. The model stimulated raising $3 billion new debt to fund content. Total new debt is the $16 billion, new WACC is the 11.13%, and the impact, the WACC decreased by 9.2 basis points. Now for a more strategic comparison, where we can compare Netflix with Disney and Amazon. So we see that for capital structure notes, Netflix is 6% debt, which is under leveraged. Disney, which has 30% debt, is optimized leverage. And then Amazon has a very diverse business model as well. So a quick analysis of these is that Netflix's WACC is significantly higher than Disney's, and this is primarily due to capital structure. Disney utilizes a 30% debt load, allowing them to replace expensive equity with tax advantage debt. Netflix's reliance on the 94% equity financing keeps their hurdle rate high.

Now our fourth step is to validate, to actually check the accuracy and sense check. So this stage checks analysis for mathematical accuracy and also economic logic. So the economic logic check, ranking of all the costs. So we know the cost of equity should be higher than the cost of debt. So we can check that in the past. The WACC must fall between the cost of equity and the cost of debt. So the WACC here is 11.22%. The cost of equity is 4.58% and the cost of debt is 11.65% and this 11.22% is in between these two. So it did pass. A sensitivity logic check. So the logic adding debt, which is cheaper capital, should lower the WACC assuming that the beta and ratings don't deteriorate immediately. So to check the WACC dropped from 11.22% to 11.13%, so it confirms that the tax yield benefit is functioning correctly in the model. Some more external benchmarking, Netflix is a high growth media tech stock with a beta of 1.3. A WACC of 11.22% is consistent with high growth peers, Whereas Disney, which has an 8.2% WACC, represents a mature and diversified conglomerate, the spread makes intuitive sense given the risk profiles of step five, which is our evolve.

This stage essentially critiques the analysis and suggests how it could be improved by using dynamic variables rather than systematic assumptions. The critique of the static assumptions. One critique is that a constant cost of debt. The current model assumes that the bond yield remains at 5.8% after issuing the $3 billion of new debt. In order to evolve from this, in reality, increasing leverage might jeopardize the BBB plus rating. A drop in these or a decrease would increase the yield, potentially erasing the WACC benefit. With a constant beta, the model assumes that beta stays at 1.3. The evolution of this, taking on debt, increases the financial risk for shareholders, and we should use the Hamada equation to un-lever the current beta and re-lever at the new capital structure to see if the cost of equity actually rises, offsetting the cheap debt. And then some project specific things, the model currently applies a flat international risk premium. Instead of this, instead of a flat 2% added, we should calculate a specific WACC for the international regions by using the country risk premiums for specific target markets. For example, South Korea versus India versus France.

Lastly, our reflection. So what are some of the key takeaways that we took away that I took away from this problem and challenge? This stage essentially just synthesizes all the findings into core lessons learned. The first key takeaway I gained was that leverage is underutilized. Netflix is currently inefficient and efficiently capitalized with only six percent debt. It is paying a premium for its capital, which is 11.22%. And the analysis proves that increasing debt levels, even considerably by $3 billion, lowers the hurdle rate and creates shareholder value through the tax yield. My second key takeaway was that one rate does not fit all. The analysis highlights the danger of using a single corporate WACC for all decisions. If Netflix uses 11.22%, a firm-wide WACC would evaluate risky international projects. It may accept the value-destroying investments. So your recommendation for this is an adoption of a tiered hurdle rate, 11.22% for domestic content and 13.22% for national expansion.

And then lastly, my last key takeaway was that the Disney gap is structural. Netflix cannot simply become Disney by borrowing money. Disney's lower WACC, 8.2%, is driven partially by leverage, but also by lower business risk, which is a lower beta. Netflix must accept a higher cost of capital as a price of being a pure play growth competitor, but should still optimize its debt mix to narrow the gap. Thank you.

Answer: Hi everybody, my name is Jacob and today we're going to be going through my session 9 weekly video assignment which covers the cost of capital analysis. I'm in this case referring to Netflix. Um obviously we're going to be using the driver framework in order to solve this problem. First working through the define and discover stage as well as represent and then getting into the implementation stage and the rest of them using our Google Collab analysis. So here's an overview of the assignment, but let's get straight into the define and discover stage to kind of solve our problem. The first step of define and discover is to really figure out the objective um as well as the guiding question. So what are we actually solving? Um and then overall how are we going to get through that? So our objectives is to analyze the cost of capital for Netflix by calculating its weighted average cost of capital under both current and perspective capital structures and to use this analysis to make a strategic recommendation on capital structure and investment hurdle rates. And our guiding question for this is eventually what is the optimal capital structure strategy for Netflix that minimizes weighted average cost of capital while ade adequately funding strategic content investments and how does this compare to industry fears peers like Disney to do this we're going to rely on the following hypothetical known parameters that were given in the statement of the problem for equity Netflix has a market capitalization of 200 billion and an equity beta of 1.3 which is shown right here, which signals a higher systematic risk than the general market. So a beta of 1.0 is the average. 1.3 is a little bit higher. For debt, we're going to actually use the market value of 13 billion because when you're calculating debt, you use that market value. And then that pre-tax yield rate of 5.8% for those tripleB plus related bonds. And then crucially, we're going to use this 21% corporate tax rate right here to help calculate the tax shield benefit of DEX. The tax shield explains that the interest expense on debt is actually taxdeductible, making debt cheaper than equity and requiring us to use it after c after tax cost of debt when looking at different calculations. And then finally, some market conditions we have right here. We have a risk-free rate of 4.5%, our market risk premium of 5 1.5% and then the media industry average rate is between 8 and 8 to 10%. So, our analysis is going to look at five key and core outputs right here, including the Netflix current weighted average cost of capital, the cost of capital after a $3 billion debt issuance. And then we're going to look at project specific weighted average cost of capital as in US content versus international content or can compare it to Disney and explain the differences from there. And then at the end, we're going to recommend optimal capital structure strategy and go through everything as a whole. So now that we're finished with the define and discover stage, let's jump straight into the representation side of things. This stage not only showcases the necessary formulas, but it also builds out a flowchart for this analysis. We already got through the define and the solver stage. We're going to go through represent in a second. We're just going to define the financial formulas and break down our analysis journey. Then we're going to get into the implementation side. We're going to calculate some key data values using Google Collab. Then we're going to go validate. We're going to sensitivity analysis evolve. We're going to look at a risk assessment and compare it the two companies together and then reflect it. We're going to talk about the optimal strategy and explain a little bit more on those specific things. These two specific necessary financial formulas are the weighted average cost of capital and the cost of equity. So the weighted average cap cost of capital is the main one. That's the first one. That simply is the minimum acceptable rate of return that a company must earn on an existing asset base to satisfy long-term investors both equity and debt. The weighted average cost of capital in this situation is also the primary hurdle rate for evaluating average risk projects. So, your weighted average cost of capital is equal to your weight of equity multiplied by your cost of equity plus your weight of debt times the pre-tax cost of debt and then multiplied by that corporate tax rate right over here. And it's important to look at these using the market values because market values reflect the opportunity cost to investors. And then this little corporate tax rate right over here is 21%. It's that tax shield because debt is actually better than equity because you can write off a little bit of taxes. Then the other stat is that cost of equity. It's the capital assets pricing model which we've covered a little bit earlier on in our analysis which calculates the expected return on equity by relating systematic risk to the expected return of the market. Looks at time value of money and everything like that. So your equity right here is equal to your risk-free rate plus your equity beta which in this case is 1.3 times your market risk premium which is 5 1.5%. It's always important to look at that tax tax shield effect which highlights the financial advantage of debt because interest payments are taxdeductible. They reduce non- tax they reduce taxable income which is important to look at which effectively actually lowers the cost of debt relative to equity. It's the primary reason that increasing leverage actually reduces your weighted average cost of capital. So now that we got the bulk of the basics out of the way, let's jump straight into the Google Collab where we're going to actually look at the actual values and everything like that. So we worked through the implementation side of things where we're going to do that basic weighted average cost calculations and using that capital assets pricing model that we described earlier. This provides the hard numbers for Netflix's cost of capital, which addresses the technical requirements that we need. So, we bring in all the financial parameters and then we simply just define the formulas that we're going to be using. And then in scenario one and two, scenario one is the current weighted average cost of capital. And then scenario two after a $3 billion debt issuance, which helps to cover a little bit more of our analysis. So, we can look right here.
